Award.AwardTitle: RUI: Characterizing the Sources, Fates, and Transformation Products of Conjugated, Free, and Halogenated Estrogens in a Sewage-Impacted River

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1606190
Griffith

Globally, wastewater can be a significant source of carbon, nutrients, and contaminants to surface waters. Endocrine disrupting chemicals such as steroidal estrogens, which have adverse effects on aquatic vertebrates at low concentrations, are among the compounds which can be in the wastewater. This study will be accomplished through a combination of laboratory, field, and modeling experiments, and will take advantage of previously optimized analytical techniques in the PIs laboratory.

The overarching goal of this study is to improve the understanding of the fundamental processes that control wastewater derived sources and the environmental fate of estrogens and halogenated estrogens in aquatic systems. This study has the potential to transform our understanding of estrogen flux from typical wastewater treatment plants that utilize activated sludge secondary treatment and hypochlorite-based disinfection. The objectives of this project use a combination of laboratory, field, and modeling experiments to address: 1) halogenated estrogen formation and distribution in wastewater treatment plant effluent, 2) photolysis and biodegradation at environmentally relevant concentrations, and, 3) fate of halogenated estrogens in a sewage-impacted rivers. The data collected during this project will provide direct numerical inputs into simple mass balance and transport models that will be used to predict estrogen concentrations in the Willamette River, which is representative of many rivers that receive combined inputs from wastewater and storm water. This project will generate kinetic data and transformation product information for a range of estrogen structures that can be used to develop quantitative structure-activity relationships in the future, parameterize existing fate models, and determine the impact on the formation and fate of similar pharmaceuticals and organic contaminants in wastewater and natural waters. The PI and media experts at Mind Open Media will produce and distribute podcasts focused on the concepts and applications of wastewater treatment, and, the fate of chemicals in the environment. The PI will provide the research findings to state entities with a vested interest in wastewater treatment technologies and the health of river systems. Lastly, the project also funds undergraduate students to conduct research at a larger institution where they will be able to utilize the mass spectrometry facilities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Municipal wastewater effluent contains a variety of estrogen hormones capable of threatening fish populations in sewage-impacted waters. Most previous research has focused on the potent "free" estrogens, though we know that chlorine-based wastewater disinfection is commonplace and produces a raft of novel halogenated derivatives.

This research project was designed to improve our understanding of the processes controlling the sources and environmental fate of halogenated estrogens in a large sewage-impacted river system. The project sought to (1) characterize the distribution of halogenated estrogens in wastewater effluent, (2) quantify estrogen degradation rates in river water under realistic conditions, (3) identify byproduct structures and estrogenic potencies, and (4) develop a model describing river estrogen dynamics based on dilution, biodegradation, and photolysis.

 

Research Outcomes:

In this work, we found detectable levels of halogenated estrogens in all of the wastewater effluent samples, though the distribution of estrogen families varied by season and treatment plant due to differences in sunlight intensity, wastewater flow, and treatment efficiency. Dilution was important year-round as estrogens in wastewater effluent mixed into the large volume of Willamette River water. During a heavy rainfall event, we found high concentrations of the more labile glucuronide conjugates in partially treated combined sewer runoff, though estrogen concentrations in the river did not increase appreciably as a result.

The rate at which estrogens were degraded by sunlight (photolysis) and microbial communities (biodegradation) depended on a wide range of factors. In general, estrogen biodegradation occurred on timescales of days to weeks. We observed faster biodegradation for all estrogens in the presence of river sediment and when estrogen concentrations were elevated (e.g., ug/L). Interestingly, halogenated estrogen photolysis was significantly faster (minute timescales) than both free estrogen photolysis and biodegradation. It seems that inadvertently halogenating estrogens during wastewater disinfection makes them much more susceptible to destruction by photolysis. Moreover, the byproducts of estrogen photolysis were found to have very low estrogenic potency. Together these findings have important implications for understanding the persistence and risk of estrogens and other pharmaceuticals with phenol functional groups in wastewater and receiving waters.

 

Broader Impacts:

This project has made contributions in areas that are directly related to our research findings as well as through activities that support education, research infrastructure, and public engagement.

Our data directly support the on-going work of environmental engineers to optimize wastewater treatment technologies and develop contaminant fate models that can help us avoid problems, predict likely contaminant hot spots, and inform mitigation efforts.

Collaborations have strengthened the research infrastructure at Willamette University, a primarily undergraduate institution (PUI), providing students with valuable hands-on experience using a variety of high-end mass spectrometers. Outreach efforts with Dr. Ari Daniel have resulted in two audio stories focused on the environmental fate of estrogen hormones. Both pieces were broadcast nationally (NPR; Living on Earth) and distributed widely online.

The project supported one postdoctoral researcher, who is currently a tenure-track professor at a PUI, and provided extended research experiences for 12 undergraduate students. The postdoc and 9 of the undergraduates belong to groups typically underrepresented in STEM.
